01.text: This is the beginning of a new part of the story where Jesus begins to teach the crowds, using parables, about the kingdom of heaven.
These events happened on the same day as those in the previous chapter. (See: [[:en:obe:other: biblicaltimeday]])
It is implied that he sat down to teach the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is not mentioned at whose house Jesus was staying.

01.ref: so he got into a boat
01.text: It is implied that Jesus got into a boat because it would make it easier to teach the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This was probably an open, wooden fishing boat with a sail. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

03.text: Jesus describes the kingdom of heaven by telling a parable about a person who sows seeds.

03.ref: Jesus said many things to them in parables
03.text: "Jesus told them many things in parables"
"Look" or "Listen." This word calls attention to what is to be said next. AT: "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you"

03.ref: a farmer went out to sow seed
03.text: "a farmer went out to scatter seeds in a field"
This refers to a "path" next to the field. The ground there would have been hard from people walking on it.
This is ground full of rocks with just a thin layer of soil on top of the rocks.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the sun scorched the plants, and they became too hot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

07.text: Jesus finishes telling a parable about a person who sows seeds.
"choked the new sprouts." Use your word for the way weeds prevent other plants from growing well.
"produced a crop" or "grew more seeds" or "gave fruit"

07.ref: some one hundred times as much, some sixty, and some thirty
07.text: You can make clear the understood information as was done in the UDB. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

This is a way of referring to everyone listening. AT: "Everyone who is listening to me." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:11:13|11:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "listen" means paying attention. AT: "must pay careful attention to what I am saying." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:11:13|11:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

10.text: Jesus explains to his disciples why he teaches with parables.

10.ref: You have been given the privilege of understanding mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, but to them it is not given
10.text: This can be translated with the active form and supplying implied information. AT: "God has given you the privilege of understanding mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, but God has not given it to these people" or "God has made you able to understand mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, but he has not enabled these people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is plural and refers to the disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

10.ref: mysteries of the kingdom of heaven
10.text: Here "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule. The phrase "kingdom of heaven" occurs only in the book of Matthew. If possible, try to keep it in your translation. AT: "the secrets about our God in heaven and his rule" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"whoever has understanding" or "whoever receives what I teach"
This can be translated in active form. AT: "God will give him more understanding" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"whoever does not have understanding" or "whoever does not receive what I teach"

10.ref: even what he has will be taken away from him
10.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will take away even what he has" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

13.text: Jesus continues to explain to his disciples why he teaches in parables.
In verse 14, Jesus quotes the prophet Isaiah to show that the people's failure to understand Jesus' teaching is a fulfillment of prophecy.
All occurrences of "them" and "they" refer to the people in the crowd.

13.ref: Though they are seeing, they do not see; and though they are hearing, they do not hear, or understand.
13.text: Jesus uses this parallelism to tell and emphasize to the disciples that the crowd refuses to understand God's truth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

13.ref: although they see, they do not really see
13.text: The second use of "see" here means understand. It can be made explicit what they see. AT: "though they see the things I do, they do not understand them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

13.ref: although they hear, they do not really hear, neither do they understand
13.text: It can be made explicit what the people hear. AT: "though they hear what I say, they do not understand what I truly mean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

13.ref: To them the prophecy of Isaiah is fulfilled, that which says
13.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "They are fulfilling what God said long ago through the prophet Isaiah"

13.ref: While hearing you will hear, but you will in no way understand; while seeing you will see, but you will in no way perceive
13.text: This begins a quote from the prophet Isaiah about the unbelieving people of Isaiah's day. Jesus is using this quote to describe the very crowd that was listening to him. These statements are again parallel and emphasize that the people refuse to understand God's truth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

13.ref: While hearing you will hear, but you will in no way understand
13.text: "You will hear things, but you will not understand them." You can make explicit what the people will hear. AT: "You will hear what God says through the prophets, but you will not understand its true meaning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

13.ref: while seeing you will see, but you will in no way perceive
13.text: You can make explicit what the people will see. AT: "you will see what God does through the prophets, but you will not understand it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

15.text: Jesus finishes quoting the prophet Isaiah.

15.ref: For this people's heart ... I would heal them
15.text: In 13:15 God describes the people of Israel as if they have physical diseases that cause them to be unable to learn, to see, and to hear. God wants them to come to him so he will heal them. This is all a metaphor describing the people's spiritual condition. It means the people are stubborn and refuse to receive and understand God's truth. If they would, then they would repent and God would forgive them and welcome them back as his people. If the meaning is clear, keep the metaphor in your translation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

15.ref: this people's heart has become dull
15.text: Here "heart" refers to the mind. AT: "these people's minds are slow to learn" or "these people can no longer learn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
They are not physically deaf. Here "hard of hearing" means they refuse to listen and learn God's truth. AT: "they refuse to use their ears to listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
They have not literally closed their eyes. This means they refuse to understand. AT: "they refuse to use their eyes to see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

15.ref: so they should not see with their eyes, or hear with their ears, or understand with their hearts, so they would turn again
15.text: "so that they are not able to see with their eyes, hear with their ears, or understand with their heart, and as a result turn again."

"have me heal them." This means God would heal them spiritually by forgiving their sins and receiving them again as his people.  AT: "have me receive them again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

16.text: Jesus finishes explaining to his disciples why he teaches with parables.

16.ref: But blessed are your eyes, for they see; and your ears, for they hear
16.text: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Jesus is emphasizing that they have pleased God because they have believed what Jesus has said and done. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

16.ref: But blessed are your eyes, for they see
16.text: Here "eyes" refers to the whole person. AT: "You are blessed because your eyes are able to see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
All occurrences of these words are plural and refer to the disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

16.ref: and your ears, for they hear
16.text: Here "ears" refer to the whole person. You can also make clear the understood information. AT: "and you are blessed because your ears are able to hear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"I tell you the truth." This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.
You can make explicit what they have seen. AT: "the things you have seen me do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit what they have heard. AT: "the things you have heard me say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

18.text: Here Jesus begins to explain to his disciples the parable about a person who sows seeds, which he began in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:03|13:3]].
Here "word" refers to a message. And "kingdom" refers to God's rule as king. AT: "the message about God's rule as king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

18.ref: the evil one comes and snatches away what has been sown in his heart
18.text: Jesus speaks of Satan causing the person to forget what he has heard as if he were a bird snatching the seed from the ground. AT: "The evil one causes him to forget the message that he has heard just like a bird that snatches away seed from the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Try to use a word that means to grab something away from someone who is the rightful owner.

18.ref: what has been sown in his heart
18.text: This can be translated in active form: AT: "the message that God sowed in his heart" or "the message that he heard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "heart" refers to the mind of the hearer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

18.ref: This is the seed that was sown beside the road
18.text: "This is the meaning of the seed that was sown beside the road" or "The road where seed was sown represents this person"
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:03|13:4]].

20.text: Jesus continues to explain to his disciples the parable about a person who sows seeds.

20.ref: What was sown on rocky ground
20.text: The phrase "what was sown" refers to seed that fell. AT: "The seed that fell on rocky ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

20.ref: What was sown on rocky ground is
20.text: "The rocky ground where seed was sown represents" or "The rocky ground where seed fell fell represents"

20.ref: the person who hears the word
20.text: In the parable, the seed represents the word.
This represents God's message. AT: "the message" or "God's teaching" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Believing the word is spoken of as receiving it. AT: "joyfully believes it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

20.ref: yet he has no root in himself and he endures for a while
20.text: "Yet he has shallow roots and only lasts for a little while." The root represents what makes a person continue to believe God's message. AT: "But like a plant that does not grow deep roots, he only endures for a little while" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "falls away" means to stop believing. AT: "immediately he falls away" or "he quickly stops believing the message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

22.text: Jesus continues to explain to his disciples the parable about a person who sows seeds.
This refers to seed that was sown or that fell. AT: "The seed that was sown" or "The seed that fell"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

22.ref: What was sown among the thorn plants
22.text: "the ground with the thorn plants where seed was sown"
Here "the word" represents God's message. AT: "the message" or "God's teaching" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

22.ref: the cares of the world and the deceitfulness of riches choke the word
22.text: Jesus speaks about the cares of the world and the deceitfulness of riches distracting a person from obeying God's word as if they were weeds that could wind around a plant and keep it from growing.  AT: "as weeds prevent good plants from growing, the cares of the world and the deceitfulness of riches keep this person from listening to God's word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the things in this world that people worry about"

Jesus describes "riches" as if it were a person who could deceive someone. This means people think having more money will make them happy, but it will not. AT: "the love of money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

The person is spoken of as if he were a plant. Being unfruitful represents being unproductive. AT: "he becomes unproductive" or "he does not do what God wants." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

22.ref: What was sown on the good soil
22.text: "The good soil where seeds were sown"

22.ref: He bears fruit and makes a crop
22.text: The person is spoken of as if he were a plant. AT: "Like a healthy plant that bears a crop of fruit, he is productive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

22.ref: yielding one hundred times as much as was planted, some sixty, and some thirty times as much
22.text: The phrase "as much as was planted" is understood following each of these numbers. AT: "Some people produce 100 times as much as was planted, some produce 60 times as much, and some produce 30 times as much." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:07|13:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

24.text: Here Jesus describes the kingdom of heaven by telling a parable about a field with both wheat and weeds growing in it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

24.ref: The kingdom of heaven is like a man
24.text: The translation should not equate the kingdom of heaven to a man, but rather the kingdom of heaven is like the situation described in the parable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

24.ref: The kingdom of heaven is like
24.text: Here "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. The phrase "kingdom of heaven" is used only in Matthew. If possible, use "heaven" in your translation. AT: "When our God in heaven shows himself to be king, it will be like" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"good food seeds" or "good grain seeds." The audience probably thought that Jesus was talking about wheat. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These weeds look like food plants when they are young, but their grain is poison. AT: "bad seed" or "weed seeds" (UDB)
"When the wheat seeds sprouted" or "When the plants came up"
"then people could see there were weeds in the field also"

27.text: Jesus continues to tell a parable about a field with both wheat and weeds growing in it.
This is the same person who sowed good seed in his field.

27.ref: did you not sow good seed in your field?
27.text: The servants used a question to emphasize their surprise. AT: "you sowed good seed in your field!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The landowner probably had his servants plant the seeds. AT: "we sowed" ([[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "us" refers to the servants.

29.text: Jesus concludes the parable about a field with both wheat and weeds growing in it.

29.ref: I will say to the reapers, "First pull out the weeds and tie them in bundles to burn them, but gather the wheat into my barn."
29.text: You can translate this as an indirect quote (AT): "I will tell the reapers to first gather up the weeds and tie them in bundles to burn them, then gather the wheat into my barn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
a farm building that can be used for storing grain

31.text: Jesus describes the kingdom of heaven by telling a parable about a very small seed that grows into a very big plant. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

31.ref: The kingdom of heaven is like
31.text: Here "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. The phrase "kingdom of heaven" is used only in Matthew. If possible, use "heaven" in your translation. AT: "When our God in heaven shows himself to be king, it will be like." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:24|13:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
a very small seed that grows into a large plant (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

31.ref: This seed is indeed the smallest of all other seeds
31.text: Mustard seeds were the smallest seeds known to the original hearers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
A mustard plant can grow about 2 to 4 meters tall.

33.text: Jesus describes the kingdom of heaven by telling a parable about the effect that yeast has on flour. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

33.ref: The kingdom of heaven is like yeast
33.text: The kingdom is not like the yeast, but the spread of the kingdom is like the spreading of the yeast. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

33.ref: The kingdom of heaven is like
33.text: Here "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. The phrase "kingdom of heaven" is used only in Matthew. If possible, use "heaven" in your translation. AT: "When our God in heaven shows himself to be king, it will be like." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:24|13:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Say "a large amount of flour" or use a term that your culture uses for measuring large amounts of flour. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])

33.ref: until all the dough had risen
33.text: The implied information is that the yeast and the three measures of flour were made into dough for baking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

34.text: Here the author quotes from the Psalms to show that Jesus' teaching in parables fulfilled prophecy.

34.ref: All these things Jesus said to the crowds in parables. And without parables he said nothing to them
34.text: Both sentences mean the same thing. They are combined to emphasize that Jesus taught the crowds only with parables. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This refers to what Jesus taught beginning at [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:01|13:1]].

34.ref: he said nothing to them without a parable
34.text: "he taught them nothing except by parables." The double negative can be expressed in a positive way. AT: "everything he taught them he said in parables" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

34.ref: what had been said through the prophet might come true, when he said
34.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "he made come true what God told one of the prophets to write long ago" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an idiom that means to speak. AT: "I will speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "things that God has kept hidden" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

34.ref: from the foundation of the world
34.text: "since the beginning of the world" or "since God created the world"

36.text: Here the scene shifts to the house where Jesus and his disciples were staying. Jesus begins to explain to them the parable of the field that had both wheat and weeds, which he told beginning in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:24|13:24]].
"went indoors" or "went into the house where he was staying"
Here "sons of" means to belong to or to have the same character as someone or something. AT: "the people who belong to the kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "kingdom" refers to God the king. AT: "of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

36.ref: the sons of the evil one
36.text: Here "sons of" means to belong to or to have the same character as someone or something. AT: "the people who belong to the evil one" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

40.text: Jesus finishes explaining to his disciples the parable of the field with both wheat and weeds.

40.ref: Therefore, as the weeds are gathered up and burned with fire
40.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "Therefore, as people gather up weeds and burn them in the fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

40.ref: The Son of Man will send out his angels
40.text: Here Jesus is speaking of himself. AT: "I, the Son of Man, will send out my angels" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This is a metaphor for the fires of hell. If the term "furnace" is not known, "oven" can be used. AT: "fiery furnace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This represents extreme sadness and suffering. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:08:11|8:12]].
If this simile is not understandable in your language, you can use: "be as easy to see as the sun." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

This is a way of referring to everyone listening. AT: "Everyone who is listening to me." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:11:13|11:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "listen" means paying attention. AT: "must pay careful attention to what I am saying." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:11:13|11:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

44.text: Jesus describes the kingdom of heaven by telling two parables about people who sold their possessions to purchase something of great value. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
In these two parables, Jesus uses two similes to teach his disciples what the kingdom of heaven is like. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

44.ref: The kingdom of heaven is like
44.text: Here "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. The phrase "kingdom of heaven" is used only in Matthew. If possible, use "heaven" in your translation. AT: "When our God in heaven shows himself to be king, it will be like." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:24|13:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

44.ref: like a treasure hidden in a field
44.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "a treasure that someone had hidden in a field" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
a very valuable and precious thing or collection of things

44.ref: sells everything he possesses, and buys that field
44.text: The implied information is that the person buys the field to take possession of the hidden treasure. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

44.ref: like a man who is a merchant looking for valuable pearls
44.text: The implied information is that the man was looking for valuable pearls that he could buy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
a trader or wholesale dealer who often obtains merchandise from distant places

A "pearl" is a smooth, hard, shiny, white or light-colored bead formed inside mollusks in the sea and highly prized as a gem or to make into valuable jewelry. AT: "fine pearls" or "beautiful pearls" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

47.text: Jesus describes the kingdom of heaven by telling a parable about fishermen who use a large net to catch fish. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

47.ref: the kingdom of heaven is like a net
47.text: The kingdom is not like the net, but the kingdom draws all kinds of people like a net catches all kinds of fish. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

47.ref: the kingdom of heaven is like
47.text: Here "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. The phrase "kingdom of heaven" is used only in Matthew. If possible, use "heaven" in your translation. AT: "When our God in heaven shows himself to be king, it will be like." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:24|13:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

47.ref: like a net that was cast into the sea
47.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "like a net that some fishermen cast into the sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

47.ref: drew it up on the beach
47.text: "pulled the net up onto the beach" or "pulled the net ashore"

49.text: Jesus explains the parable about fishermen who use a large net to catch fish.
"come out" or "go out" or "come from heaven"

49.ref: the wicked from among the righteous
49.text: These nominal adjectives can be stated as adjectives. AT: "the wicked people from the righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"The angels will throw the wicked people"

This is a metaphor for the fires of hell. If the term "furnace" is not known, "oven" can be used. AT: "fiery furnace." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:40|13:42]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This represents extreme sadness and suffering. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:08:11|8:12]].

51.text: Jesus describes the kingdom of heaven by telling a parable about a person who manages a household. This is the end of the part of the story about Jesus teaching the crowds about the kingdom of heaven through using parables.

51.ref: Have you understood all these things?" The disciples said to him, "Yes."
51.text: If necessary, both direct quotations can be translated as indirect quotations. AT: "Jesus asked them if they had understood all this, and they said that they did understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

51.ref: has become a disciple to the kingdom of heaven
51.text: Here "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. The phrase "kingdom of heaven" is used only in the book of Matthew. If possible, keep "heaven" in your translation. AT: "has learned the truth about our God in heaven, who is king" or "has submitted himself to God's rule" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

51.ref: is like a man who is the owner of a house, who draws out old and new things from his treasure
51.text: Jesus speaks another parable. He compares scribes, who know very well the scriptures that Moses and the prophets wrote, and who also now accept Jesus' teachings, to a house owner who uses both old and new treasures. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
A treasure is a very valuable and precious thing or a collection of things. Here it may refer to the place where these things are stored, the "treasury" or "storeroom."

51.ref: Then it came about that when
51.text: This phrase shifts the story from Jesus' teachings to what happened next. AT: "Then" or "After"

54.text: This is the beginning of a new part of the story that runs through [[:en:bible:notes:mat:17:26|17:27]], where the writer tells of continued opposition to Jesus' ministry and teaching about the kingdom of heaven. Here, the people of Jesus' home town reject him.
"his hometown." This refers to the town of Nazareth where Jesus grew up. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The pronoun "their" is referring to the people of the region.

54.ref: Where does this man get his wisdom and these miracles from?
54.text: "How can an ordinary man like this be so wise and do such great miracles?"

54.ref: Is not this man the carpenter's son? Is not his mother's called Mary? Are not his brothers James, Joseph, Simon, and Judas? Are not all his sisters with us? Where did he get all these things?"
54.text: The crowd uses this series of questions to show their surprise that an ordinary person from their region could do all these things. AT: "Jesus is just a carpenter's son. We know his mother, Mary. And his brothers James, Joseph, Simon, and Judas, and his sisters all live among us. An ordinary man should not be able to do these things!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
A carpenter is someone who makes things with wood or stone. If "carpenter" is not known, "builder" can be used.

57.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The people of Jesus' hometown took offense at him" or "The people rejected Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

57.ref: A prophet is not without honor
57.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "A prophet receives honor everywhere" or "People everywhere honor a prophet" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

57.ref: he did not do many miracles there
57.text: "Jesus did not do many miracles in his own hometown"
